Add Text Overlay to Fact 2 Image

parameter.name: caption
parameter.value: ={{ $('AI Agent').item.json.output.socialCaption }} Check out the video on #ShockedHistory

parameters.text:
=Given this motivational theme: "{{ $json.selectedTitle }}", fact part 1: "{{ $json.selectedFactPart1 }}", and fact part 2: "{{ $json.selectedFactPart2 }}", provide:

1. Three distinct visual descriptions for a gritty, desaturated garage gym aesthetic:
   - Image 1: Focus on the main theme/title with weathered equipment and dramatic lighting
   - Image 2: Visual representation of fact part 1 with industrial elements
   - Image 3: Visual representation of fact part 2 with raw concrete and metal textures

2. Social media content for each image

Return your response in this exact JSON format:
{
  "originalTheme": "{{ $json.selectedTitle }}",
  "factPart1": "{{ $json.selectedFactPart1 }}",
  "factPart2": "{{ $json.selectedFactPart2 }}",
  "image1": {
    "context": "Gritty garage gym visual for the main theme",
    "socialTitle": "Catchy title for main theme",
    "socialCaption": "Caption with hashtags for main theme"
  },
  "image2": {
    "context": "Gritty garage gym visual for fact part 1",
    "socialTitle": "Catchy title for fact part 1", 
    "socialCaption": "Caption with hashtags for fact part 1"
  },
  "image3": {
    "context": "Gritty garage gym visual for fact part 2",
    "socialTitle": "Catchy title for fact part 2",
    "socialCaption": "Caption with hashtags for fact part 2"
  }
}

nodes.name: Add Text Overlay to Fact 1 Image
Add Text Overlay to Fact 2 Image

output.factPart1: Where do most of your gym results really come from?
output.factPart2: The Pareto Principle. Roughly 80% of your results will come from just 20% of your exercises and efforts. Identify and master that 20%.

image1.context: A dimly lit garage gym with a rustic barbell and dumbbells on a weathered wooden rack, dramatic shadows emphasizing the '80/20' painted faintly on the wall.
image1.socialTitle: Master the 20% for 80% of Your Gains
image1.socialCaption: The 80/20 Rule in action—where focus meets results. #ParetoPrinciple #GymLife #Efficiency

image2.context: Close-up of a chipped kettlebell on a concrete floor with an industrial fan in the background, symbolizing the core of gym efforts.
image2.socialTitle: Where Do Your Results Really Come From?
image2.socialCaption: Pinpoint the 20% that drives your progress—stop wasting time on the rest. #GymHacks #WorkoutSmart #Efficiency

image3.context: A chalkboard in the garage gym scrawled with '80/20' alongside a rusted weight plate, surrounded by raw metal dumbbells.
image3.socialCaption: Identify your key exercises and dominate them. #ParetoGains #TrainSmarter #NoFluff

json.selectedFactPart1: Where do most of your gym results really come from?
json.selectedFactPart2: The Pareto Principle. Roughly 80% of your results will come from just 20% of your exercises and efforts. Identify and master that 20%.

json.TITLE: Abundance Mindset
json.FACT PART 1: Think there's only a limited amount of success to go around?
json.FACT PART 2: That's a scarcity mindset. An abundance mindset sees opportunity everywhere, believing one person's success doesn't diminish their own.

json.TITLE: Accountability Mirror
json.FACT PART 1: Who is the one person you can never lie to about your effort and discipline?
json.FACT PART 2: The person in the mirror. Use a partner or a journal as that mirror to hold yourself to the standard you committed to.

json.TITLE: Action Over Feeling
json.FACT PART 1: Should you wait until you feel motivated to take action?
json.FACT PART 2: It's the other way around. Action is the spark that creates motivation, not the other way around. Don't wait, just start.

json.TITLE: Analysis Paralysis
json.FACT PART 1: Why does overthinking a decision often lead to making no decision at all?
json.FACT PART 2: Having too many options or too much information overwhelms the brain's executive function, leading to inaction as a defense mechanism.

json.TITLE: Antifragility
json.FACT PART 1: What's stronger than being resilient?
json.FACT PART 2: Being antifragile. It means you don't just withstand shocks and chaos; you actually get stronger and better because of them.

json.TITLE: Auditory Exclusion
json.FACT PART 1: Ever been so focused on a heavy lift that the world goes silent?
json.FACT PART 2: That's auditory exclusion. Under extreme stress or focus, your brain actively filters out sounds it deems unimportant to survival.

json.TITLE: BDNF Secret
json.FACT PART 1: Want to literally grow your brain and protect it from aging?
json.FACT PART 2: Intense exercise triggers the release of BDNF (Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor), a protein that builds and repairs brain cells. Lift to get smarter.

json.TITLE: Beginner's Mind
json.FACT PART 1: Why do experts sometimes fail to see obvious solutions?
json.FACT PART 2: Their knowledge can blind them. A "beginner's mind" approaches problems without preconceptions, allowing for more creative solutions.

json.TITLE: Brain Priming
json.FACT PART 1: Can simple words change how you behave?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes. Exposing your brain to certain words or ideas (like "strength" or "success") subconsciously primes you to act in alignment with them.

json.TITLE: Building Confidence Through Competence
json.FACT PART 1: What's the most sustainable way to build genuine self-confidence in your fitness journey?
json.FACT PART 2: Through developing competence: mastering skills, achieving tangible progress, and proving to yourself what you are capable of through consistent effort.

json.TITLE: Building Habits Through Identity
json.FACT PART 1: Instead of focusing on outcomes, what's a more powerful way to create lasting habits in your fitness journey?
json.FACT PART 2: Focus on your identity. Ask yourself, "What kind of person do I want to be?" and build habits that align with that identity.

json.TITLE: Building Mental Resilience
json.FACT PART 1: Life in the iron game (and life in general) throws punches. How do you learn to absorb them?
json.FACT PART 2: By cultivating mental resilience: the ability to bounce back from stress, adversity, and setbacks with strength and determination.

json.TITLE: Burning the Boats
json.FACT PART 1: How do you make failure an absolute impossibility?
json.FACT PART 2: You "burn the boats." By eliminating your path of retreat, you commit 100% to the fight forward. Victory or death; there is no other option.

json.TITLE: Catastrophizing
json.FACT PART 1: Do you turn a small mistake, like a missed rep, into a catastrophe?
json.FACT PART 2: This cognitive distortion magnifies a single negative event into a sign of complete and utter failure. Isolate the event from your identity.

json.TITLE: Choice Architecture
json.FACT PART 1: Want to make better choices without using willpower?
json.FACT PART 2: Design your environment. Make good choices the easiest path and bad choices difficult. Your environment dictates your actions.

json.TITLE: Cognitive Dissonance
json.FACT PART 1: Ever feel deep discomfort when your actions don't match your beliefs?
json.FACT PART 2: That's cognitive dissonance. Your mind craves consistency and will force you to either change your beliefs or your actions.

json.TITLE: Cognitive Load
json.FACT PART 1: Why is it impossible to learn a new, complex lift when the gym is chaotic?
json.FACT PART 2: Your working memory has a limited capacity. Too much external noise or internal stress creates excessive cognitive load, preventing learning.

json.TITLE: Cognitive Reappraisal
json.FACT PART 1: How can you change your emotional response to a stressful situation?
json.FACT PART 2: By changing your interpretation of it. Reappraise the anxiety before a big lift not as fear, but as excitement and readiness.

json.TITLE: Cognitive Reframing
json.FACT PART 1: How can you change your feelings about a situation without changing the situation?
json.FACT PART 2: Change the story you tell yourself about it. Reframe "I have to do this" into "I get to do this."

json.TITLE: Confirmation Bias
json.FACT PART 1: Ever notice you only find evidence that supports what you already believe?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain actively filters reality to protect your ego, ignoring facts that contradict your current beliefs.

json.TITLE: Cortisol Control
json.FACT PART 1: Why does chronic stress sabotage your gym gains and mental clarity?
json.FACT PART 2: Chronic stress floods you with cortisol, a hormone that breaks down muscle, stores fat, and impairs cognitive function. Master stress, master growth.

json.TITLE: Creating a Growth-Oriented Environment
json.FACT PART 1: Does your surroundings influence your mindset in your garage gym?
json.FACT PART 2: Absolutely. Surround yourself with reminders of your goals, inspiring figures, and a challenging yet supportive atmosphere.

json.TITLE: Cultivating a Bias for Action
json.FACT PART 1: Do you tend to overthink or take decisive action in pursuit of your goals?
json.FACT PART 2: Developing a bias for action—a tendency to act rather than procrastinate—is crucial for turning intentions into results.

json.TITLE: Cultivating Mental Clarity
json.FACT PART 1: How do you cut through the mental fog and stay focused on what truly matters in your training and life?
json.FACT PART 2: Through practices like mindfulness, journaling, and prioritizing tasks to eliminate distractions and enhance mental sharpness.

json.TITLE: Cultivating Self-Discipline
json.FACT PART 1: Is self-discipline an innate trait or a skill you can develop in your garage?
json.FACT PART 2: It's a muscle. Like any muscle, it grows stronger with consistent training through small, deliberate acts of willpower.

json.TITLE: Decision Fatigue
json.FACT PART 1: Why are your worst decisions made at the end of the day?
json.FACT PART 2: Your willpower is like a muscle. It gets exhausted from making too many small choices, leading to poor impulse control later.

json.TITLE: Declarative Memory
json.FACT PART 1: How does saying your goals out loud make them more real?
json.FACT PART 2: It transfers the goal from a vague idea into a concrete, declarative memory, which your brain treats as a more serious command.

json.TITLE: Deindividuation
json.FACT PART 1: Ever lose yourself in the energy of a group training session?
json.FACT PART 2: That's deindividuation. A loss of self-awareness in groups can lead you to push past limits you'd normally obey when training alone.

json.TITLE: Delayed Gratification
json.FACT PART 1: What's the number one predictor of long-term success in life?
json.FACT PART 2: The ability to delay gratification. Sacrificing a small, immediate reward for a much larger one later is a superpower.

json.TITLE: Deliberate Practice
json.FACT PART 1: Just showing up to the gym isn't enough. What's the secret to real progress?
json.FACT PART 2: Deliberate practice: focused, strategic training with specific goals and constant feedback. It’s about quality over quantity.

json.TITLE: Developing a Growth Mindset in the Face of Plateaus
json.FACT PART 1: What happens when your progress in the gym seems to stall? How do you respond?
json.FACT PART 2: A growth mindset sees plateaus not as limitations, but as opportunities to learn, adapt your training, and break through to new levels.

json.TITLE: Developing a Strong Inner Dialogue
json.FACT PART 1: What kind of conversations are you having with yourself during a tough set or a challenging moment?
json.FACT PART 2: Cultivating a strong, positive, and encouraging inner dialogue is key to pushing past perceived limitations.

json.TITLE: Developing Emotional Agility
json.FACT PART 1: How do you prevent negative emotions from derailing your progress in the iron sanctuary?
json.FACT PART 2: By practicing emotional agility: acknowledging your feelings without judgment, learning from them, and continuing to move forward aligned with your values.

json.TITLE: Developing Grit: Passion and Perseverance
json.FACT PART 1: What's the combination of traits that allows individuals to pursue long-term goals with unwavering dedication, even in the face of setbacks?
json.FACT PART 2: Grit: the combination of passion for a long-term goal and the perseverance to overcome obstacles along the way.

json.TITLE: Developing Self-Awareness in Your Training
json.FACT PART 1: How well do you understand your body's limits, strengths, and weaknesses in your garage gym?
json.FACT PART 2: Cultivating self-awareness allows you to train smarter, avoid injury, and optimize your progress based on your individual needs.

json.TITLE: Dopamine Detox
json.FACT PART 1: Feeling unmotivated and distracted all the time?
json.FACT PART 2: You might be overstimulated. Intentionally reducing high-dopamine activities (like social media) resets your brain's reward system.

json.TITLE: Eating the Frog
json.FACT PART 1: What's the secret to winning your day before it has barely begun?
json.FACT PART 2: Eat the frog. Do your hardest, most dreaded task first thing in the morning. The rest of your day will feel easy by comparison.

json.TITLE: Ego Depletion
json.FACT PART 1: Is your willpower a limited resource that can actually run out during the day?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes. Psychologists call it ego depletion. Each act of self-control uses up mental energy, making the next one harder. Refuel with rest.

json.TITLE: Embracing Discomfort
json.FACT PART 1: What's the secret weapon for growth that most people actively avoid?
json.FACT PART 2: Deliberately seeking discomfort. It expands your comfort zone, builds mental fortitude, and unlocks new levels of potential.

json.TITLE: Embracing the Process, Not Just the Outcome
json.FACT PART 1: Where does true satisfaction and growth come from in your pursuit of fitness and self-improvement?
json.FACT PART 2: From embracing the process: the daily dedication, the challenges overcome, and the continuous learning, regardless of immediate results.

json.TITLE: Emotional Contagion in Training
json.FACT PART 1: Can one person's bad attitude ruin the entire gym's atmosphere?
json.FACT PART 2: Absolutely. Emotions are contagious. A training partner with a weak mindset will weaken you. A strong one will strengthen you. Choose wisely.

json.TITLE: Emotional Granularity
json.FACT PART 1: What's the difference between saying "I feel bad" and "I feel frustrated and impatient"?
json.FACT PART 2: That's emotional granularity. The ability to specifically name your emotions gives you immense power to manage them effectively.

json.TITLE: Emotional Regulation
json.FACT PART 1: Are you your emotions, or do you simply experience them?
json.FACT PART 2: You are the observer. Learning to name your emotions ("I feel anger") separates you from them and gives you power over your reactions.

json.TITLE: Enclothed Cognition
json.FACT PART 1: Why does wearing your gym gear make you feel more athletic and ready to train?
json.FACT PART 2: That's enclothed cognition. The clothes you wear carry symbolic meaning and can systematically influence your thoughts and actions.

json.TITLE: Eudaimonia
json.FACT PART 1: What is the ultimate goal beyond just being "happy"?
json.FACT PART 2: Eudaimonia. A Greek concept meaning human flourishing and living a life of virtue. It's about striving to be your highest self, not just chasing pleasure.

json.TITLE: Fear of Failure
json.FACT PART 1: Is your fear of failure really about the failure itself?
json.FACT PART 2: No. It's often a fear of the shame or judgment you believe will come with it. The fear is social, not practical.

json.TITLE: Finding Meaning in Struggle
json.FACT PART 1: How can you transform tough workouts and challenging times into sources of strength?
json.FACT PART 2: By finding meaning in the struggle. Connecting your efforts to a larger purpose and understanding the value of overcoming adversity.

json.TITLE: Finding Your "Why"
json.FACT PART 1: When the initial excitement fades, what fuels your long-term dedication?
json.FACT PART 2: A powerful "why"—your core reason for pursuing your goals. It provides intrinsic motivation and resilience in tough times.

json.TITLE: Finding Your Inner Anchor
json.FACT PART 1: In the face of external pressures and distractions, what can keep you grounded and focused on your path?
json.FACT PART 2: Cultivating an inner anchor—a set of core values and principles that guide your decisions and actions.

json.TITLE: First Principles Thinking
json.FACT PART 1: Want to solve problems like a genius?
json.FACT PART 2: Break a problem down to its most basic, fundamental truths and reason up from there, ignoring assumptions and common beliefs.

json.TITLE: Functional Fixedness
json.FACT PART 1: Do you see a weight plate only as a weight plate?
json.FACT PART 2: Or can it be used for calf raises, pullovers, or farmer's walks? Overcoming functional fixedness means seeing things for what they can do.

json.TITLE: Goodhart's Law
json.FACT PART 1: What happens when a measure of progress becomes the main goal?
json.FACT PART 2: It ceases to be a good measure. Chasing numbers on the scale can lead to bad habits. Focus on the process, not just the metric.

json.TITLE: Gratitude Practice
json.FACT PART 1: What’s a two-minute habit that can rewire your brain for happiness?
json.FACT PART 2: Daily gratitude practice. It trains your mind to scan for positives, increasing serotonin and dopamine levels over time.

json.TITLE: Group Polarization
json.FACT PART 1: What happens when a group of people with the same mindset train together?
json.FACT PART 2: Their beliefs become even more extreme and convicted. This is group polarization. Use it to forge an ironclad, supportive culture.

json.TITLE: Growth vs. Fixed
json.FACT PART 1: What's the one word that separates success from stagnation?
json.FACT PART 2: The word "yet." It shifts your brain from a state of limitation to a state of possibility.

json.TITLE: Habit Loops
json.FACT PART 1: Why are bad habits so incredibly hard to break?
json.FACT PART 2: Every habit has a three-part loop: Cue, Routine, Reward. To break a habit, you must replace the routine, not just resist it.

json.TITLE: Harnessing the Power of Your Inner Critic (Constructively)
json.FACT PART 1: Is the voice of self-doubt always negative? How can you use it?
json.FACT PART 2: It can be a source of valuable feedback. Learn to identify its valid points and use them to improve, without letting it paralyze you.

json.TITLE: Harnessing Your Inner Fire for Motivation
json.FACT PART 1: What's the internal drive that pushes you through tough workouts and challenging times? How do you stoke it?
json.FACT PART 2: Your inner fire—your deep-seated passion, purpose, and will to succeed. Nurture it by connecting with your "why" and celebrating your progress.

json.TITLE: Heuristics vs. Algorithms
json.FACT PART 1: Are you using a mental shortcut or a proven formula to solve a problem?
json.FACT PART 2: A heuristic is a fast mental shortcut (a rule of thumb). An algorithm is a step-by-step process. Know which one you're using and why.

json.TITLE: Hofstadter's Law
json.FACT PART 1: Why do you always underestimate how long it will take to reach a new PR?
json.FACT PART 2: Hofstadter's Law states that any complex task will always take longer than you expect, even when you account for Hofstadter's Law. Plan for it.

json.TITLE: Home-Field Advantage
json.FACT PART 1: Why do you almost always lift better and feel stronger in your own gym?
json.FACT PART 2: It's a real psychological phenomenon. Familiarity, territoriality, and ritual all contribute to a measurable performance boost.

json.TITLE: Hormesis
json.FACT PART 1: Ever wonder why a little stress, like a brutal workout, actually makes you stronger?
json.FACT PART 2: That's hormesis. Your body adapts to low-dose stressors by building powerful defense systems, making you more resilient overall.

json.TITLE: Hyperbolic Discounting
json.FACT PART 1: Why does the immediate comfort of the couch often beat the future reward of being fit?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain values immediate rewards far more than future ones. This is hyperbolic discounting. To win, make the future reward feel present.

json.TITLE: Ideomotor Effect
json.FACT PART 1: How can your thoughts create tiny, involuntary physical movements?
json.FACT PART 2: The Ideomotor Effect shows that simply thinking about an action can prime your muscles to perform it. Visualization is a physical act.

json.TITLE: Impostor Syndrome
json.FACT PART 1: Ever feel like a fraud, despite your success?
json.FACT PART 2: It's a sign of high achievement. It means your standards for yourself are growing faster than your current level of confidence.

json.TITLE: Inattentional Blindness
json.FACT PART 1: Can you be looking directly at something and not see it at all?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes. If your attention is focused intensely on one task, you can become blind to other unexpected, but obvious, things. Focus is a filter.

json.TITLE: Intrinsic Motivation
json.FACT PART 1: Why does doing something you love feel effortless?
json.FACT PART 2: That's intrinsic motivation. The reward is the activity itself, not some external prize. This is the most powerful form of fuel.

json.TITLE: Learning from Failure (The Right Way)
json.FACT PART 1: How do the truly successful view failure?
json.FACT PART 2: As a learning opportunity, a crucial step on the path to mastery. They analyze what went wrong without self-blame and adjust accordingly.

json.TITLE: Learning to Say "No"
json.FACT PART 1: What's a crucial skill for protecting your mental energy and staying focused on your priorities?
json.FACT PART 2: The ability to say "no" to commitments that don't align with your goals or drain your resources.

json.TITLE: Loss Aversion
json.FACT PART 1: Why does the fear of losing strength feel twice as bad as the joy of gaining it?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain is hardwired for loss aversion. The pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of an equal gain.

json.TITLE: Maslow's Hammer
json.FACT PART 1: Are you trying to solve every problem in the gym with the same solution?
json.FACT PART 2: If all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail. Broaden your mental toolkit to use the right approach for the right problem.

json.TITLE: Mental Models
json.FACT PART 1: How do the world's best thinkers make such great decisions?
json.FACT PART 2: They use mental models—frameworks for thinking—like "Inversion," where you think about what you want to avoid, not just what to achieve.

json.TITLE: Mental Toughness
json.FACT PART 1: What separates those who quit when it gets hard from those who push through?
json.FACT PART 2: Mental toughness isn't about being fearless; it's about acting despite the fear. It’s a skill honed through adversity.

json.TITLE: Mind-Body Connection
json.FACT PART 1: Can your physical posture change your mental state?
json.FACT PART 2: Absolutely. Adopting a "power pose"—standing tall and open—for just two minutes can increase confidence and decrease stress hormones.

json.TITLE: Mind-Muscle Connection
json.FACT PART 1: Is lifting just about moving weight, or is it about intention?
json.FACT PART 2: A strong mind-muscle connection—consciously feeling the target muscle work—is proven to increase muscle activation and growth.

json.TITLE: Mindful Presence
json.FACT PART 1: Where does most of your suffering and anxiety actually come from?
json.FACT PART 2: It comes from regretting the past or fearing the future. True peace is found by grounding yourself in the present moment.

json.TITLE: Narrative Identity
json.FACT PART 1: Who are you, really?
json.FACT PART 2: You are the story you tell yourself. If you want to change your life, you must first change the narrative you live by.

json.TITLE: Neuroplasticity
json.FACT PART 1: Think your brain is set in stone after a certain age?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain physically reorganizes itself based on your repeated thoughts, habits, and focus. You can literally build a new mind.

json.TITLE: Occam's Razor
json.FACT PART 1: When your progress stalls, what's usually the simplest explanation?
json.FACT PART 2: The one that's most likely true. Are you overtraining, or did you just not sleep well? Occam's Razor says start with the simplest answer.

json.TITLE: Optimism Bias
json.FACT PART 1: Why do most people believe they are less likely to experience negative events?
json.FACT PART 2: The optimism bias is a cognitive illusion that makes us underestimate future risks, which is essential for taking chances and pursuing goals.

json.TITLE: Pareto Principle (80/20 Rule)
json.FACT PART 1: Where do most of your gym results really come from?
json.FACT PART 2: The Pareto Principle. Roughly 80% of your results will come from just 20% of your exercises and efforts. Identify and master that 20%.

json.TITLE: Parkinson's Law
json.FACT PART 1: Why does a task expand to fill the time you allot for it?
json.FACT PART 2: That's Parkinson's Law. Give yourself one hour for the gym, it'll take an hour. Give yourself 45 minutes, you'll find a way.

json.TITLE: Prefrontal Cortex
json.FACT PART 1: What part of your brain is the CEO of your discipline and willpower?
json.FACT PART 2: Your prefrontal cortex. Every time you choose the hard rep over quitting, you are physically strengthening the command center of your mind.

json.TITLE: Premeditatio Malorum
json.FACT PART 1: How do Stoics build unbreakable resilience before ever facing a challenge?
json.FACT PART 2: They practice "Premeditatio Malorum"—the premeditation of evils. By visualizing what could go wrong, they prepare their minds for any outcome.

json.TITLE: Psychological Resilience
json.FACT PART 1: What makes some people bounce back from adversity so quickly?
json.FACT PART 2: They see setbacks as temporary, contained to one area of life, and not personal. This "3 P's" model builds resilience.

json.TITLE: Reactance Theory
json.FACT PART 1: Why do you immediately want to do something when someone tells you that you can't?
json.FACT PART 2: That's reactance. It's a psychological urge to resist threats to your freedom. Use this defiance to crush self-imposed limitations.

json.TITLE: Self-Determination Theory
json.FACT PART 1: What are the three core needs you must meet for peak motivation?
json.FACT PART 2: Autonomy (control over your actions), Competence (feeling effective), and Relatedness (connecting with others). Nail these, and drive becomes automatic.

json.TITLE: Shadow Work
json.FACT PART 1: What are the disowned parts of yourself that secretly control your behavior?
json.FACT PART 2: Your "shadow." This is the part of your unconscious mind with repressed weaknesses and desires. Integrating it is key to wholeness.

json.TITLE: Sharpening the Axe
json.FACT PART 1: Why is taking time to rest and learn just as important as the work itself?
json.FACT PART 2: If you have six hours to chop a tree, spend the first four sharpening the axe. Preparation, recovery, and learning are not wasted time.

json.TITLE: Sleep & Mindset
json.FACT PART 1: What's the most overlooked factor in maintaining a positive mindset?
json.FACT PART 2: Sleep. A single night of poor sleep can significantly increase activity in the brain's fear and anxiety centers.

json.TITLE: Social Contagion
json.FACT PART 1: Did you know that moods and mindsets are as contagious as a virus?
json.FACT PART 2: You subconsciously absorb the emotional states and beliefs of those around you. Protect your mind by curating your social environment.

json.TITLE: Spaced Repetition
json.FACT PART 1: What's the secret to mastering a new lift or skill permanently?
json.FACT PART 2: Spaced repetition. Practice the skill at increasing intervals over time. This tells your brain the information is critical to remember.

json.TITLE: Stoic Mindset
json.FACT PART 1: How can you find peace in a world you can't control?
json.FACT PART 2: Focus only on what you can control: your own thoughts, judgments, and actions. Release the rest. That is the core of stoicism.

json.TITLE: Sunk Cost Fallacy
json.FACT PART 1: Ever keep doing something you hate just because you've already invested so much?
json.FACT PART 2: That's the Sunk Cost Fallacy. Your brain irrationally values what you've already lost over making the right choice for the future.

json.TITLE: Survivorship Bias
json.FACT PART 1: Why is it dangerous to only study the habits of successful people?
json.FACT PART 2: You ignore the vast number who used the exact same habits and failed. This is survivorship bias. Focus on principles, not just personalities.

json.TITLE: System 1 vs. System 2
json.FACT PART 1: Are you making decisions with your gut or your head?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain has two systems. System 1 is fast, intuitive, and emotional (your gut). System 2 is slow, deliberate, and logical (your head). Know which one is in charge.

json.TITLE: The "Flow State"
json.FACT PART 1: What's the secret to losing track of time while being highly productive?
json.FACT PART 2: The "flow state." It happens when the challenge of a task is perfectly matched to your skill level, silencing your inner critic.

json.TITLE: The Amygdala Hijack
json.FACT PART 1: Ever overreact in a split second and regret it later?
json.FACT PART 2: That was an amygdala hijack. Your brain's threat center took over before your rational mind could even engage. Train to pause.

json.TITLE: The Anchoring Bias
json.FACT PART 1: Does the first number you see affect all your future judgments?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes. If you see someone lift 400 lbs first, your judgment of a 300 lb lift will be "anchored" by that initial number.

json.TITLE: The Anti-Fragile Ego
json.FACT PART 1: What's the difference between a big ego and a strong ego?
json.FACT PART 2: A big ego is fragile and shatters with criticism. A strong, anti-fragile ego welcomes feedback and uses it to grow even stronger.

json.TITLE: The Art of Letting Go
json.FACT PART 1: What do you need to release to make space for growth and progress?
json.FACT PART 2: Letting go of limiting beliefs, past failures, and the need for external validation. Embrace the present moment and your potential.

json.TITLE: The Availability Heuristic
json.FACT PART 1: Why do you worry more about a rare, dramatic injury than a common, simple one?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain judges the likelihood of an event by how easily it can recall an example. This is the availability heuristic.

json.TITLE: The Baader-Meinhof Phenomenon
json.FACT PART 1: Ever learn a new word or exercise and suddenly see it everywhere?
json.FACT PART 2: That's a frequency illusion. Your brain, now primed to see it, selectively notices it more, making it seem like it's suddenly ubiquitous.

json.TITLE: The Backfire Effect
json.FACT PART 1: What happens when a deeply held belief is challenged by facts?
json.FACT PART 2: It often gets even stronger. The Backfire Effect shows that our brains protect core beliefs by rejecting contradictory evidence.

json.TITLE: The Ben Franklin Effect
json.FACT PART 1: How can asking someone for a small favor make them like you more?
json.FACT PART 2: When they do you a favor, their brain justifies it by deciding they must like you. We align our beliefs with our past actions.

json.TITLE: The Bystander Apathy
json.FACT PART 1: Why might no one correct your bad form in a crowded commercial gym?
json.FACT PART 2: Bystander Apathy. Everyone assumes someone else will step in, leading to collective inaction. Don't rely on others for your safety.

json.TITLE: The Bystander Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Why do people fail to act in a crisis when they're in a crowd?
json.FACT PART 2: They assume someone else will. The diffusion of responsibility makes individuals feel less personal obligation to intervene.

json.TITLE: The Cocktail Party Effect
json.FACT PART 1: How can you hear your name whispered across a loud, crowded gym?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain is always listening for personally relevant information. This is your reticular activating system (RAS) at work.

json.TITLE: The Comfort Zone
json.FACT PART 1: Why does staying comfortable actually lead to more anxiety?
json.FACT PART 2: Your comfort zone shrinks over time. Avoiding small discomforts makes you less resilient and more fearful of the unknown.

json.TITLE: The Consistency Principle
json.FACT PART 1: How do you get yourself to follow through on big goals?
json.FACT PART 2: Start by making a small, public commitment. Our brains have a powerful, subconscious need to remain consistent with our past selves.

json.TITLE: The Curse of Knowledge
json.FACT PART 1: Once you master a lift, why is it so hard to teach it to a beginner?
json.FACT PART 2: The curse of knowledge makes it difficult to remember what it was like to not know something. You forget the struggles of a novice.

json.TITLE: The Cynefin Framework
json.FACT PART 1: How do you make decisions when you don't know what to do?
json.FACT PART 2: The Cynefin framework helps you identify if a problem is simple, complicated, complex, or chaotic, each requiring a different approach.

json.TITLE: The Default Effect
json.FACT PART 1: What's the easiest way to guarantee you stick to a good habit?
json.FACT PART 2: Make it the default option. Lay out your gym clothes the night before. Your brain loves the path of least resistance.

json.TITLE: The Desire for Control
json.FACT PART 1: What is one of the most fundamental drivers of human motivation?
json.FACT PART 2: The innate desire for control over one's life and environment. Lifting weights is a direct way to exert and experience that control.

json.TITLE: The Dichotomy of Control
json.FACT PART 1: What's the Stoic's key to unwavering inner peace in the chaos of life?
json.FACT PART 2: Understanding the dichotomy of control: focusing solely on what you can influence (your thoughts, actions) and accepting what you can't.

json.TITLE: The Diderot Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Ever buy one new piece of gym gear and suddenly feel the urge to upgrade everything else?
json.FACT PART 2: That's the Diderot Effect. One new possession can create a spiral of consumption as you seek to create a cohesive whole.

json.TITLE: The Discipline of Detachment (Stoic Principle)
json.FACT PART 1: How can you protect your inner peace from external outcomes in your training and life?
json.FACT PART 2: Through the discipline of detachment: focusing on the process and your effort, rather than being solely fixated on results you can't fully control.

json.TITLE: The Dunning-Kruger Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Why do incompetent people often seem the most confident?
json.FACT PART 2: They lack the self-awareness to accurately judge their own skills, creating a cognitive bias of illusory superiority.

json.TITLE: The Dunning-Kruger Effect (Revisited)
json.FACT PART 1: What happens right after you break through the peak of "Mount Stupid"?
json.FACT PART 2: You fall into the "valley of despair," where you suddenly realize how much you don't know. This is a critical step towards true mastery.

json.TITLE: The Einstellung Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Why does your first successful solution to a problem often blind you to better ones?
json.FACT PART 2: Your mind gets stuck on a familiar solution, preventing you from seeing more efficient or creative alternatives. Always be willing to adapt.

json.TITLE: The Empathy Gap
json.FACT PART 1: Why is it so hard to remember the pain of a brutal workout when you're resting?
json.FACT PART 2: The empathy gap. It's difficult to predict how you'll behave in a "hot" state (like exhaustion) when you're in a "cold" state (like resting).

json.TITLE: The Endowment Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Why do you value something you own more than an identical item you don't?
json.FACT PART 2: The Endowment Effect. Ownership creates an emotional attachment that makes you overvalue your own possessions and ideas.

json.TITLE: The Feynman Technique
json.FACT PART 1: How can you truly test if you understand a concept or a movement?
json.FACT PART 2: Try to teach it to a complete beginner in simple terms. If you can't, you don't understand it well enough yourself.

json.TITLE: The Forer Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Why do generic motivational quotes sometimes feel profoundly personal?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain is primed to accept vague statements as specifically tailored to you, especially if they are positive. Be a discerning consumer of advice.

json.TITLE: The Forgetting Curve
json.FACT PART 1: Why do you forget almost everything you learn so quickly?
json.FACT PART 2: Without active recall, you're destined to forget. The brain discards information it doesn't regularly retrieve to save energy.

json.TITLE: The Framing Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Can you change your reality just by changing your words?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes. Framing a 90% success rate is motivating, while a 10% failure rate is discouraging. They're the same fact. Master your frame.

json.TITLE: The Fundamental Attribution Error
json.FACT PART 1: When someone else fails, is it their character? When you fail, is it the situation?
json.FACT PART 2: That's the fundamental attribution error. We tend to blame others' character for their failures, but our own situation for ours. Grant others grace.

json.TITLE: The Galatea Effect
json.FACT PART 1: What is the most powerful set of expectations that governs your life?
json.FACT PART 2: Your own. The Galatea Effect is the power of an individual's self-expectations. If you believe you can, you are already halfway there.

json.TITLE: The Halo Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Why do we assume attractive people are also smart and kind?
json.FACT PART 2: It's a cognitive bias called the Halo Effect, where one positive trait creates an overall "halo" that influences our other judgments.

json.TITLE: The Hard-Easy Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Do you overestimate your ability on hard tasks and underestimate it on easy ones?
json.FACT PART 2: That's the Hard-Easy effect. This bias leads to misplaced confidence and can cause you to neglect fundamentals while rushing into advanced work.

json.TITLE: The Hawthorne Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Ever notice you perform better in the gym when you know someone is watching?
json.FACT PART 2: That's the Hawthorne Effect. The simple act of being observed can change your behavior and increase your performance. Use it.

json.TITLE: The Hedonic Treadmill
json.FACT PART 1: Why doesn't achieving a big goal make you happy for very long?
json.FACT PART 2: We quickly adapt to new circumstances, and our happiness level returns to its baseline. The joy is in the pursuit, not the prize.

json.TITLE: The Ikea Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Why do you value the results you built yourself more than those given to you?
json.FACT PART 2: The Ikea Effect. We place a disproportionately high value on things we partially created ourselves. Your struggle imbues your results with meaning.

json.TITLE: The Illusion of Transparency
json.FACT PART 1: Do people know you're nervous or struggling just by looking at you?
json.FACT PART 2: You feel they do, but they don't. We vastly overestimate how much our internal states are visible to others.

json.TITLE: The Importance of Having a Challenging Vision
json.FACT PART 1: What kind of goals truly ignite your inner fire and push you beyond your perceived limits?
json.FACT PART 2: A challenging vision—a compelling future you are striving towards—provides powerful motivation and direction.

json.TITLE: The Importance of Rest and Recovery (Mental Aspect)
json.FACT PART 1: It's not just about physical recovery. What does your mind need to recharge and stay sharp?
json.FACT PART 2: Mental rest: intentional breaks from demanding tasks, mindfulness practices, and activities that help you de-stress and refocus.

json.TITLE: The Importance of Self-Compassion
json.FACT PART 1: When you fall short of your goals, what's the most constructive way to respond to yourself?
json.FACT PART 2: With self-compassion. Treating yourself with the same kindness and understanding you would offer a friend in the same situation.

json.TITLE: The Importance of Solitude
json.FACT PART 1: In our hyper-connected world, what's a crucial practice for self-awareness and mental clarity?
json.FACT PART 2: Regular periods of solitude. It allows for introspection, reflection, and a deeper understanding of your inner self.

json.TITLE: The Impostor Cycle
json.FACT PART 1: Feeling like a fraud? Does that feeling push you to work harder, leading to more success and a bigger feeling of being a fraud?
json.FACT PART 2: That's the Impostor Cycle. Break it by internalizing your successes and attributing them to your own skill and hard work.

json.TITLE: The Inner Citadel
json.FACT PART 1: Where is the one fortress that no one can ever conquer?
json.FACT PART 2: Your mind. The Stoics called it the Inner Citadel. You can retreat there at any moment to find peace, regardless of external chaos.

json.TITLE: The Internal Locus of Control
json.FACT PART 1: Do you believe your life is determined by fate or your own actions?
json.FACT PART 2: A strong internal locus of control—believing you are the primary driver of your outcomes—is crucial for taking ownership and achieving goals.

json.TITLE: The Johari Window
json.FACT PART 1: What are the "blind spots" in your own character that everyone else can see?
json.FACT PART 2: The Johari Window is a model for self-awareness. You must actively seek feedback to understand the parts of yourself you're blind to.

json.TITLE: The Just-World Fallacy
json.FACT PART 1: Do you believe that if you just work hard, you are guaranteed success?
json.FACT PART 2: The world isn't inherently fair. Believing it is can lead to immense bitterness. Focus on your effort, but accept that outcomes aren't guaranteed.

json.TITLE: The Law of Attraction
json.FACT PART 1: Is "The Law of Attraction" just wishful thinking?
json.FACT PART 2: No, it's about focus. What you consistently focus on, you will start to notice and act upon, creating opportunities you'd otherwise miss.

json.TITLE: The Law of Diminishing Returns
json.FACT PART 1: Is more training always better?
json.FACT PART 2: No. At a certain point, the benefit you get from each additional set or session decreases significantly and risk of injury increases.

json.TITLE: The Law of Instrument
json.FACT PART 1: Are you trying to solve every fitness problem with your favorite exercise?
json.FACT PART 2: This is an extension of Maslow's Hammer. Don't let your familiarity with one tool blind you to the existence of better ones.

json.TITLE: The Law of Requisite Variety
json.FACT PART 1: In any system, who holds the power?
json.FACT PART 2: The part with the most flexibility and options. To dominate any situation, you must be more adaptable than your environment.

json.TITLE: The Locus of Control
json.FACT PART 1: Is your life something you control, or something that happens to you?
json.FACT PART 2: An internal locus of control means you believe you are in the driver's seat. This belief is a prerequisite for taking meaningful action.

json.TITLE: The Matthew Principle
json.FACT PART 1: Why do those who are already strong seem to get stronger the fastest?
json.FACT PART 2: To those who have, more will be given. Success and advantage tend to accumulate. Momentum is a powerful, real-world force.

json.TITLE: The Need for Closure
json.FACT PART 1: Why does an unfinished workout or an unanswered question gnaw at your mind?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain has a strong need for cognitive closure. It craves firm answers and dislikes ambiguity. Use this to drive you to finish what you start.

json.TITLE: The Negativity Bias
json.FACT PART 1: Why do you remember insults more vividly than compliments?
json.FACT PART 2: It's an evolutionary survival trait. Your brain is wired to pay more attention to threats and dangers (negativity) than to positives.

json.TITLE: The OODA Loop
json.FACT PART 1: How do fighter pilots make elite decisions under extreme pressure?
json.FACT PART 2: They use the OODA loop: Observe, Orient, Decide, Act. By cycling through this process faster than your challenges, you stay in control.

json.TITLE: The Overjustification Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Can you kill your passion for lifting by getting paid for it?
json.FACT PART 2: Sometimes. When an external reward is given for an activity you love, your intrinsic motivation can decrease. Protect your "why."

json.TITLE: The Paradox of Choice
json.FACT PART 1: Does having more options make you happier?
json.FACT PART 2: No, it often leads to more anxiety and less satisfaction. Limiting your options can dramatically increase your peace of mind.

json.TITLE: The Peak-End Rule
json.FACT PART 1: How does your brain remember an entire workout?
json.FACT PART 2: It doesn't. It remembers the peak moment of intensity and how you felt at the very end. Finish every session strong to build a positive memory.

json.TITLE: The Placebo Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Can you really think yourself well?
json.FACT PART 2: Believing a treatment will work can cause your brain to release its own natural chemicals that produce real, measurable healing effects.

json.TITLE: The Planning Fallacy
json.FACT PART 1: Why do your ambitious workout plans always seem to fall apart?
json.FACT PART 2: The planning fallacy is our tendency to underestimate the time, costs, and risks of future actions, while overestimating their benefits.

json.TITLE: The Power of Affirmations (Used Correctly)
json.FACT PART 1: Can simply repeating positive statements actually change your mindset?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes, when done with intention and belief, aligning with your actions. Empty repetition is ineffective; felt affirmations can rewire your subconscious.

json.TITLE: The Power of Consistency Over Intensity
json.FACT PART 1: What's more crucial for long-term progress in your garage gym: sporadic bursts of high intensity or consistent effort?
json.FACT PART 2: Consistency. Showing up regularly and putting in the work, even when you don't feel like it, yields greater results over time.

json.TITLE: The Power of Focused Attention
json.FACT PART 1: In a world of distractions, what's your most valuable asset in achieving your goals?
json.FACT PART 2: Focused attention. The ability to concentrate deeply on the task at hand, blocking out noise and distractions.

json.TITLE: The Power of Incremental Improvement
json.FACT PART 1: How do you conquer seemingly insurmountable challenges in your fitness and life goals?
json.FACT PART 2: Through incremental improvement: focusing on getting just a little bit better each day. Small, consistent progress compounds over time.

json.TITLE: The Power of Intention Setting
json.FACT PART 1: Before each workout or each day, do you clearly define what you want to achieve?
json.FACT PART 2: Setting clear intentions provides focus, direction, and a greater sense of purpose to your actions.

json.TITLE: The Power of Journaling for Self-Reflection
json.FACT PART 1: What's a simple yet profound practice for gaining insights into your thoughts, emotions, and progress?
json.FACT PART 2: Regular journaling. It provides a space for self-reflection, tracking your journey, and identifying patterns in your mindset.

json.TITLE: The Power of Ritual
json.FACT PART 1: Why is having a consistent pre-lift routine so critical for performance?
json.FACT PART 2: Rituals signal to your brain and body that it's time to perform. They reduce anxiety, increase focus, and make excellence a habit.

json.TITLE: The Power of Self-Talk
json.FACT PART 1: Does the voice inside your head really have that much power?
json.FACT PART 2: Your internal monologue directly influences your emotional state and dictates the subconscious commands your body and mind follow.

json.TITLE: The Power of Small Wins
json.FACT PART 1: Overwhelmed by a massive goal? What's the first step to building unstoppable momentum?
json.FACT PART 2: Focus on small, achievable wins. Each success builds confidence and reinforces the belief in your ability to progress.

json.TITLE: The Practice of Gratitude for Small Things
json.FACT PART 1: Amidst the grind, what simple habit can shift your perspective towards positivity?
json.FACT PART 2: Practicing gratitude for the small things. Recognizing and appreciating the progress you've made and the resources you have.

json.TITLE: The Proteus Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Can the way you present yourself online actually change who you are?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes. The Proteus Effect shows that people conform to the behavior of their avatars or online personas. Build an identity worth living up to.

json.TITLE: The Proximity Principle
json.FACT PART 1: What is the single greatest predictor of your habits and success?
json.FACT PART 2: Proximity. You are the average of the people you spend the most time with. To upgrade yourself, upgrade your circle.

json.TITLE: The Pygmalion Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Do other people's expectations of you actually matter?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes. We subconsciously live up (or down) to the expectations others place on us, a powerful self-fulfilling prophecy.

json.TITLE: The Pygmalion Effect (Revisited)
json.FACT PART 1: Can your belief in your training partner's potential actually make them stronger?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes. The Pygmalion Effect shows that our high expectations for others can become a self-fulfilling prophecy, improving their performance.

json.TITLE: The Reciprocity Norm
json.FACT PART 1: How can a simple act of support in the gym create a powerful bond?
json.FACT PART 2: When someone helps you (like with a spot), you feel a deep-seated urge to reciprocate. This builds the foundation of a strong community.

json.TITLE: The Reversibility Principle
json.FACT PART 1: How quickly do you lose your hard-earned gains when you stop training?
json.FACT PART 2: Faster than you think. The reversibility principle, or "use it or lose it," means your body will shed adaptations it no longer needs.

json.TITLE: The Second Arrow
json.FACT PART 1: The first arrow is the pain of a failed lift. What's the second, more painful one?
json.FACT PART 2: The second arrow is your own judgment about it. It's the self-criticism and shame you add. The first is unavoidable; the second is a choice.

json.TITLE: The Self-Serving Bias
json.FACT PART 1: When you succeed, is it skill? When you fail, is it bad luck?
json.FACT PART 2: That's the self-serving bias. We attribute successes to our own character but blame failures on external factors. Take radical ownership of both.

json.TITLE: The Solomon Paradox
json.FACT PART 1: Why is it easier to solve other people's problems than your own?
json.FACT PART 2: The Solomon Paradox. We can think more rationally and wisely about others' situations because we have emotional distance from them.

json.TITLE: The Specificity Principle
json.FACT PART 1: Want to get better at squats? What's the one thing you must do?
json.FACT PART 2: Squat. The specificity principle states that your body adapts specifically to the demands placed upon it. You become what you repeatedly do.

json.TITLE: The Spotlight Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Worried everyone is noticing your every mistake?
json.FACT PART 2: They aren't. We vastly overestimate how much attention people pay to us. This is the "spotlight effect." You are mostly invisible.

json.TITLE: The Stoic Concept of Negative Visualization
json.FACT PART 1: How can contemplating what you have to lose actually increase your appreciation for what you have?
json.FACT PART 2: Through negative visualization: imagining the absence of the good things in your life to cultivate gratitude and resilience.

json.TITLE: The Stoic Ideal of Inner Independence
json.FACT PART 1: Where should your ultimate source of strength and contentment reside?
json.FACT PART 2: Within yourself. Cultivating inner independence means not relying on external factors for your well-being and sense of purpose.

json.TITLE: The Stoic Practice of Amor Fati
json.FACT PART 1: How can you find joy and purpose even in the face of hardship?
json.FACT PART 2: Through Amor Fati: loving your fate. Accepting and even embracing everything that happens, both good and bad, as part of your journey.

json.TITLE: The Stoic Practice of Memento Mori
json.FACT PART 1: How can contemplating your own mortality actually enhance your appreciation for life and fuel your actions?
json.FACT PART 2: Memento Mori: remembering that you will die. This awareness can bring a sense of urgency and focus to living a meaningful life.

json.TITLE: The Stoic Practice of Voluntary Hardship
json.FACT PART 1: Why would you intentionally subject yourself to discomfort in your training and life?
json.FACT PART 2: To build resilience, appreciate comfort, and prove to yourself that you can handle adversity. It strengthens your inner core.

json.TITLE: The Stoic Understanding of Virtue
json.FACT PART 1: What is the ultimate measure of success and fulfillment for a Stoic?
json.FACT PART 2: Living a virtuous life: acting with wisdom, justice, courage, and temperance, regardless of external circumstances.

json.TITLE: The Stoic View on External Validation
json.FACT PART 1: Should your sense of worth and progress depend on the approval of others in your fitness journey?
json.FACT PART 2: No. True strength comes from internal validation—measuring your progress against your own standards and values.

json.TITLE: The Tetris Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Ever finish a long workout and see the world in terms of reps and sets?
json.FACT PART 2: That's the Tetris Effect. Your brain gets locked into patterns from repeated activity. Use it to your advantage by focusing on positive patterns.

json.TITLE: The Tyranny of Choice
json.FACT PART 1: Does having endless workout variations actually help or hurt your progress?
json.FACT PART 2: It often hurts. The tyranny of choice can lead to paralysis and dissatisfaction. Embrace the liberating power of constraints.

json.TITLE: The Vagus Nerve
json.FACT PART 1: What's the physical link between your gut feelings and your brain's calm?
json.FACT PART 2: The vagus nerve. You can stimulate it with deep, slow breathing to physically command your body to exit "fight or flight" mode.

json.TITLE: The Value of Patience
json.FACT PART 1: In the pursuit of strength and mastery, what virtue is often underestimated?
json.FACT PART 2: Patience. True progress takes time, consistent effort, and the willingness to embrace the long game.

json.TITLE: The Yerkes-Dodson Law
json.FACT PART 1: Can being too "hyped up" for a lift actually hurt your performance?
json.FACT PART 2: Yes. The Yerkes-Dodson law shows that performance increases with arousal, but only up to a point. Too much anxiety impairs performance.

json.TITLE: The Zeigarnik Effect
json.FACT PART 1: Why can't you stop thinking about that unfinished task?
json.FACT PART 2: Your brain is hardwired to remember incomplete tasks better than completed ones, creating a mental tension that pushes for closure.

json.TITLE: The Zeigarnik Effect (Revisited)
json.FACT PART 1: How can you use the urge to finish things to your advantage?
json.FACT PART 2: Start a task for just five minutes. The Zeigarnik effect will create a mental tension that will push you to go back and complete it.

json.TITLE: Turning Obstacles into Opportunities
json.FACT PART 1: How do the mentally strong view setbacks?
json.FACT PART 2: Not as roadblocks, but as valuable feedback and opportunities to learn, adapt, and emerge stronger.

json.TITLE: Using Setbacks as Fuel
json.FACT PART 1: How can you turn disappointment into motivation in your training?
json.FACT PART 2: By using setbacks as fuel. Channeling the frustration and desire to improve into intensified effort and strategic adjustments.

json.TITLE: Victim vs. Creator
json.FACT PART 1: What's the fundamental difference between a victim and a creator mindset?
json.FACT PART 2: A victim believes life happens to them. A creator believes life happens for them, and they respond accordingly.

json.TITLE: Visualization
json.FACT PART 1: Can imagining success actually help you achieve it?
json.FACT PART 2: Elite athletes use it constantly. Visualizing an action activates the same neural pathways as actually performing it, building muscle memory.
